data.title: Sync and more translation for zh_CN
Container children resetted when editing parent
data.body:
OS: Xubuntu 15.05
Godot Version: 2.0.3 stable

Elements placed inside a Container (ScrollContainer) are resetted when the parent is manipulated. 
The changes are also not applied when playing the scene.
(See video for behavior and steps to reproduce)

Recording of the issue: https://youtu.be/EGCjYfwX3PU
Forum entry of other people having the same problem: http://godotdevelopers.org/index.php?topic=15521.0

data.title: Pixel Size property of Sprite3D is displayed as integer into the Inspector
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Official 2.0.3stable win64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

The Pixel Size property of Sprite3D accept float values, but the Inspector display it as integer.

If I want to verify the actual value of this property, I'm forced to click on it.

It could be more practical if this value was displayed as float into the inspector.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: fix stb font property names
Adding "Redraw this node" button to scene panel or scene toolbox
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Using : Godot_v2.0.3_stable_x11.64 on linuxmint 17.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After changing position or size of a child node in a container like VBoxContainer, HBoxContainer it needs to switch to another scene tab or play the edited scene to see the results of automatic arranging of child nodes. 

A "Redraw this node" button in scene panel or scene toolbox will be usefull when building complex menu panels.

data.title: drag/drop meshes into viewport
data.body: The new drag/drop features are brilliant! Would be great if you could also drag/drop a .msh file from the filesystem into the 3d viewport or the scene tree(where it would automatically create a new meshinstance node). Would make populating a 3d world much quicker then having to manually make new mesh instances each time.

data.title: OUYA gamepad joystick movement/tilting causes game to crash on OUYA.
data.body:
Windows 10, 64 bit; Godot Engine 2.0.3 (STABLE RELEASE)

What happened is that after finding out that there has been improvements and updates to export any games from godot to the OUYA, I've decided to give it a test run to see how it goes, so far it starts up nicely and the framerate doesn't seem to stutter or fail. I've pressed the O,U,Y,A buttons and the D-pad and those work very well, but however the problem is that the instant I've started to tilt the gamepad joystick, the game instantaneously crashes

I've tried separate empty projects to see if there were any instances of causing the same issue without using gdscript or any other method, but alas they all failed and crashed.

So it does export, but then later crashes after tilting the joystick on the OUYA gamepad. Could the X,Y,Z, controller axis be somehow affected by the OUYA's android OS?

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Run ADB.exe
2. Create any empty project and export it to any android or OUYA devices.
3. Test all the buttons on the OUYA gamepad controller.
4. After it crashes by tilting the OUYA gamepad joystick, run this command on ADB:
   " adb bugreport > bugreport.txt" (Should be located in the [USERNAME] folder) and see if there is
   any error related to the joystick crash.

P.S. If anybody likes to request my bug report for this issue, please let me know so then I can post and share my results.

data.title: Key modifiers (Ctrl, Alt, Meta and Shift) may be used as Input keys n…
data.body:
…ow on OSX.

Before this fix they could only be used as modifiers (for example Ctrl-K) but now they can be used as keys themselves (for example Ctrl).

data.title: Navigation in 2D/3D viewport should "wrap around" the mouse
data.body:
Blender has an handy feature since a few versions (2.70 or so?) that makes the cursor "wrap around" when it reaches the edge of the viewport while panning (in both 2D and 3D views).

I guess this requires some OS-specific code.

data.title: Add OS.is_exported()
data.body:
When exporting a game, resources get converted to binary formats. So .tscn becomes .scn, .tres becomes .res etc.
It causes trouble in my game because I use file names in parameters, and in order to load them I need to append the right extension to them. 
A current workaround would be to use OS.is_debug_build() but it doesn't exactly fulfills the required feature.
If there is not already a function for this, could `OS.is_exported()` be added to know if a game is exported or is ran from the editor? Or make it so load("test.tscn") also works if only .scn is found?

data.title: Prevent calling 'Object::cast_to' method on NULL pointer
data.body:
Make 'Object::cast_to' static which can properly handle NULL pointers
as an argument.

This patch fixes crashes on GCC 6 and makes the sanitizer happy. It
also removes some redundant checks before calling 'Object::cast_to'.

data.title: Errors in console about _get_modified_time() on Linux
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Arch Linux, Godot 2.1 Git (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/889d141ba987940c25b7465bab862752dbd14d43)

Clang `version 3.8.0 (tags/RELEASE_380/final)`

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When using resources in the editor (saving, loading, …), every so often, you will get an error like this:

```
ERROR IN: res://dynamic_fonts/dynamic_fonts/roboto_bold_32.tres
ERROR: _get_modified_time: Method/Function Failed, returning: 0
   At: drivers/unix/file_access_unix.cpp:238.
```

This error seems to be harmless.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Save and load resources around, it will eventually happen.

data.title: Placing a colon (:) on the Project Name interferes with userdata
data.body:
Windows 10 - Godot 2.0.3 (Steam)

If you have a colon on your project name, you can't access user:// since Windows filesystem won't be able to make a project directory with a colon on it's name.

i.e.:
Project name: "Example: The Coloning"
User data folder on Windows would be: "%AppData%\Roaming\Godot\app_userdata\Example: The Coloning"
But Windows can't create a folder named "Example: The Coloning", so the user directory is never created.

data.title: Random infinite loop with errors
data.body:
This one is a tough nut to crack. I got some infinite loop when interacting with Editor Settings. Sometimes when I opened it, other times when changing a value and another time when closing it. But it does not happen all of the time.

It might be a compiler bug, since I only saw it with a build compiled with GCC 6. But I'm not able to reliably reproduce and according to other reports (one by [Randy Tan on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/groups/godotengine/permalink/782484578554805/) and [other by @zaps166](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/4883#issuecomment-222436433)) it happens in different circunstances.

This is what I got in Arch Linux:

![godot editor settings infinite loop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/15656351/9028b4ee-267c-11e6-9a30-ce3dd3e9d683.png)

Also happens in Window, as per Randy Tan's report:

![13320731_10207893863999224_1818282718338960352_o](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/15656362/b766b3a8-267c-11e6-97a3-b92d4cd9a4ab.jpg)
